newsitem.title: RUSSIA: SOCCER-RUSSIA BRACED FOR BUOYANT ISRAELIS.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-RUSSIA BRACED FOR BUOYANT ISRAELIS.

text.p: Russian coach Boris Ignatiev says Israeli football has learned a lot from former Soviet exiles and poses a real threat to the group five favourites in Wednesday's World Cup qualifier in Tel Aviv.

Russia, keen to forget a dismal time at the European Championships in England, will field a side heavy with Spanish league experience against an Israeli team in buoyant mood after last month's 2-1 home win over Euro 96 finalists Bulgaria.
"This game will likely be the key to our year," Ignatiev said. "If we win, we'll not only open up a lead but have a psychological advantage over our main rivals, Israel and Bulgaria."
All three scorers in September's 4-0 home win over Cyprus -- Sporting Gijon's Yuri Nikiforov, Bologna's Igor Kolyvanov and Vladimir Beschastnykh of Racing Santander -- should start.
"There's been a fair number of players from the former Soviet Union in Israel recently," Ignatiev said.
"Toughness, discipline, a good training set-up, organisation on the pitch, the right tactics -- that's all the influence of our exports."

Russia's likely starting lineup is: Stanislav Cherchesov (Tirol Innsbruck); Viktor Onopko (Oviedo), Yuri Nikiforov (Sporting Gijon), Omari Tetradze (Alania Vladikavkaz); Andrei Kanchelskis (Everton), Valery Karpin (Valencia), Ilya Tsimbalar (Spartak Moscow), Vladislav Radimov (Zaragoza), Andrei Tikhonov (Spartak Moscow); Igor Kolyvanov (Bologna), Vladimir Beschastnykh (Racing Santander)
